MARIETTA EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Since 1855, AFCO has been delivering chemical, process, training, equipment, and distribution solutions to leaders in the food, beverage, and hospitality industries that help them operate at the best and highest levels of sanitation, productivity, and profitability. AFCO is a full-service partner throughout all areas of the client facilities and their process management. Working alongside our clients AFCO delivers expertise and hands-on support to help meet sanitation, compliance, and operational needs efficiently and cost-effectively.



The 99,000 square-foot Marietta warehouse facility serves as a site for the distribution and manufacturing of AFCO cleaning, sanitation, and maintenance products. Many of these products are manufactured under strict quality control procedures since these products are utilized in industries making consumer products, food, and beverages. AFCO provides a full range of services connected with our products, including consultation, training, equipment designed to deliver our products, and customer site service.



The peracetic acid products which are produced on site are packaged in various containers, including 330-gallon totes and 55-gallon drums. The warehouse section of the facility stores and ships these products to customers. Peracetic acid manufacturing and product packaging are conducted in a 5,200 square foot room in the facility that can be isolated from the general plant manufacturing and warehousing facilities.



Based on the materials handled, and offsite consequence analysis, the Marietta facility is characterized as a Program Level 2 facility.



AFCO implements an accidental release prevention policy to ensure compliance with the EPA RMP regulation. The accidental release prevention program includes:

other substances, fires, and health emergencies. The plan details the means to notify all workers of incidents and actions to be taken, such as site evacuation and headcount; and includes contact information for local emergency response organizations, including the Marietta Fire Department. Evacuation plans are available and evacuation escape plan maps can be found throughout the facility. The site maintains inventories of emergency equipment and supplies on site. The response plan has been reviewed with the local emergency response organizations and the Cobb County Resource Council Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).
